author: Aayush Puthran
title: Virender Sehwag retires from international cricket and IPL – Issues statement on Twitter
text:
Virender Sehwag retires from international cricket and IPL – Issues statement on Twitter By Aayush Puthran on October 20, 2015 at 3:34 PM Comments India batsman Virender Sehwag has announced his retirement from international cricket and the Indian Premier League (IPL) on his 37 th birthday. He wrote on his official Twitter page, “I hereby retire from all forms of international cricket and from the Indian Premier league. A statement will follow.” The Delhi player has played was a part of India’s 2011 World Cup and 2007 World T20 winning campaigns. He was also a part of the 2003 and 2007 World Cup winning side. In 251 One-Day Internationals (ODI) matches, he has scored 8,273 runs with a highest score of 219. In 19 T20 International (T20I), he scored 394 runs. I hereby retire from all forms of international cricket and from the Indian Premier League. A statement will follow. 
— Virender Sehwag (@virendersehwag) October 20, 2015 Sehwag had hinted at retirement on Sunday saying, “If I am not retired I will not play. I will go back to India and announce my retirement. So it isn’t official yet, people.” He said this in the Masters Champions League (MCL) press conference in Dubai. (Also Read: Virender Sehwag – A butcher with the bat, an affable simpleton without it ) 
— Virender Sehwag (@virendersehwag) October 20, 2015 
The retirement comes a few days after his former teammate Zaheer Khan to called it quits. Even as Sehwag was an aggressive batsman, he made a far greater impact in Test cricket. He is the only Indian batsman to have scored a triple century in Test cricket, one of the four batsmen to have reached that landmark in world cricket and also the only player apart from Sir Don Bradman to have recorded figures of 290+ in Test cricket thrice. He is also the only cricketer in the world to have scored two double centuries and grab a five-wicket haul in Test cricket
